item.content:encoded:
The Phantom (Erik)…..Ramin Karimloo
Christine…..Sierra Boggess
Raoul…..Hadley Fraser

This was a specially-staged production of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Phantom musical to celebrate its 25th anniversary. In addition to its all-star cast, it also featured performances from Sarah Brightman, the musical’s original Christine, and popular Phantom actors Colm Wilkinson, Anthony Warlow, and John Owen-Jones. Swedish singer Peter Joback, who was scheduled to take over the role in 2012, performed alongside the others. Also making a special appearance (though unfortunately unable to sing) was the musical’s original Phantom, Michael Crawford.

item.content:encoded:
The Phantom (Erik)…..Gerard Butler
Christine…..Emmy Rossum
Raoul…..Patrick Wilson

After 18 hugely successful years in London and with no end in sight, Andrew Lloyd Webber’s musical adaptation arrived on the big screen and was the first starring role for 16-year-old actress Emmy Rossum. It was not a strict adaptation of the musical as several parts were changed from the stage production (the most notable being the famous chandelier crash), but many of the changes (especially the torture chamber scene) were incorporated to pay homage to Gaston Leroux’s novel.

After the success of the non-musical TV miniseries, Yeston and Kopit’s original musical made its on-stage debut in 1991. Its plot and characters were exactly the same as in the miniseries, but it featured all-new songs that included “Melodie de Paris”, “Who Could Ever Have Dreamed up You?”, and “You are Music”.

item.content:encoded:
The Phantom (Erik)…..Charles Dance
Christine…..Teri Polo
Raoul…..Adam Storke (Phillipe)

Adapted from Yeston and Kopit’s musical, this made-for-TV miniseries from 1990 had the unusual distinction of filming almost all of its scenes at the actual opera house in Paris where the story is supposed to occur. It is also unusual in that it changes Raoul’s name to Phillipe, which was the name of his older brother in the book. Erik himself is gentler than usually portrayed and has not lived his life in complete solitude; he directed the opera’s affairs through the manager Gerard Carriere (Burt Lancaster), whom he also considered his friend.

item.content:encoded:
The Phantom (Erik)…..Herbert Lom (Professor Petrie)
Christine…..Heather Sears
Raoul…..Edward de Souza (Harry Hunter)

This version of Phantom was produced in 1962 by the English movie studio Hammer Film Productions, which was renowned for its horror movies. Much like the Phantom in the 1943 film, Professor Petrie (the Phantom’s name in this adaptation) starts out as a mild-mannered composer who quickly goes berserk when he suspects his music has been stolen. He begins to haunt the opera house where his stolen music will be performed, and it isn’t long before he crosses paths with the talented young singer Christine Charles.

item.content:encoded:
The Phantom (Erik)…..Claude Rains
Christine…..Susannah Foster
Raoul…..Edgar Barrier

Intended as a remake of the 1925 version–and even filmed on the same opera stage set–this 1943 version changed multiple parts of the story. Among the changes: Erik is not born with his deformity but acquires it in the course of the movie; Raoul is the chief of police, not a vicomte, and Christine has a third love interest in the baritone Anatole Garron (played by Nelson Eddy). Despite its divergence from its source material, its emphasis on and inclusion of music makes it a precursor of sorts to the widely popular Andrew Lloyd Webber musical.

Christine…..Ping Hu
Raoul…..Unknown

This adaptation of Gaston Leroux’s novel is set in China and tells the story of Song Danping, a once-famous singer who is now believed dead and haunts an abandoned theater. His protege is Sun Xiaoou, a struggling young singer who becomes the star of his acting troupe under the Phantom’s tutelage. But Song Danping is not content with merely teaching Sun Xiaoou and uses the young man to get revenge on the men who scarred his face and robbed him of the woman he loved.

The post The Phantom of the Opera (1925) appeared first on In Dreams He Came.
item.content:encoded:
The Phantom (Erik)…..Lon Chaney, Sr.
Christine…..Mary Philbin
Raoul…..Norman Kerry

This is the earliest surviving film adaptation of Gaston Leroux’s novel, and it is widely regarded as a classic for both the horror and the silent film genres. One of the biggest attractions of this version was Lon Chaney’s performance and appearance as Erik; he designed the makeup especially for this movie. Another way this movie stands out is in the accuracy with which it adheres to the plot of the book; very few other adaptations follow the original story as closely as this movie did. Although Universal would go on to become famous for movies like Dracula, Frankenstein, and The Mummy, The Phantom of the Opera was the movie that started Universal’s fame for outstanding horror films.

Christine…..Aud Egede-Nissen
Raoul…..Unknown

Nine years before Universal made its silent film classic, this German-produced adaptation was the very first movie based on Gaston Leroux’s novel. Very little is known about it today–in fact, the film itself is no longer in existence–but it still stands in history as the very first film adaptation of this classic story.
